conclusion: The problem involves an anti-aircraft missile being launched to hit an enemy aircraft flying at a constant speed and altitude.
The missile has a rocket engine that expels gas vertically downward to make it accelerate uniformly upward until it reaches 5000 meters.
The gas expulsion direction changes to an angle θ downward and to the right, causing the missile to follow a curved trajectory until it hits the aircraft.
The thrust force remains constant during the missile's flight, and the missile's mass change and air resistance are negligible.
The missile can be treated as a point mass, and g = 10 m/s².

premise: The missile starts from rest and accelerates uniformly upward with an acceleration of 10g (which is 100 m/s²) until it reaches 5000 meters altitude.
conclusion: The equation to find the time taken to reach 5000 meters is h = (1/2) a t², where h = 5000 m, a = 100 m/s².

premise: The velocity at the end of this phase is v = a t = 100 m/s² * 10 s

conclusion: After 10 seconds, the missile has reached 5000 meters altitude and has a velocity of 1000 m/s upward.
From this point on, the gas expulsion direction changes to an angle θ downward and to the right.
The thrust force F is constant in magnitude but changes direction to θ downward and to the right.

premise: During the initial phase, the thrust force was entirely upward, countering gravity and causing an upward acceleration of 10g.
